prompt: You wake up and there are already 12 things competing for your attention. Before any of it — do you know what actually matters today?
In the last week, how often did you decide what mattered before the day decided for you?
When your week got loud and urgent, were you choosing your direction — or just responding to whoever showed up?
Think about the last 7 days. Were you leading your day, or was your day leading you?
When someone dropped something urgent in your lap, did you have a clear enough sense of your own priorities to sort it out — or did the urgency just win?
How often in the last week did you start the day knowing your one most important thing?
When the week got chaotic, did you have an anchor — a clear intention you could return to — or were you improvising all week?
In the last 7 days, how often did you set a direction before checking your messages in the morning?
When things got hard this week, did you still know what you were building toward?
Think about a moment this week when you felt pulled in multiple directions. Did you know which direction was actually yours?
When you were exhausted, did you still make intentional choices — or did you just let the day happen?
The people around you — do they seem like they know where they're going? Or does the day just happen to them too?
In the last month, how often did you check in with yourself before making a big decision — not just react?
When everything felt like a priority, how often did you stop and name the one thing that actually was?
Under real pressure — deadline, conflict, depletion — did your intentions hold, or did you go into autopilot?
This past month, were you intentional more often than you were reactive?
In the last week — when something genuinely good happened, did you let it actually land? Or did you move straight to the next thing?
Think about the last 7 days. Was there a moment where something made you smile, laugh, or feel something warm? Did you notice it?
How often this week did something small — a conversation, a view, a small win — actually register as good?
When your week was hard, did you find anything in it worth a moment of appreciation — or were you just surviving?
In the last week, did you share something positive with someone around you — not to perform, just because it was real?
When you're under pressure, do you still notice the good? Or does your filter only catch what's wrong?
Think about someone close to you. When did you last genuinely celebrate something with them — not just acknowledge it, actually celebrate it?
In the last 7 days, how often did you allow yourself to fully feel something going well — not minimize it, not dismiss it?
When a win happened this week — yours or someone else's — did it register as meaningful? Or did you move past it immediately?
How often in the last week did you laugh, or feel genuinely light, even for a few minutes?
The people around you — do they experience you as someone who notices the good? Or mostly as someone who spots the problems?
When things were difficult this week, did you look for one honest good thing — or did the weight of it all crowd everything else out?
In the last month, have you been the person who lifts the room — or the person who doesn't notice the room?
When something you worked on actually came together, did you take a breath and feel it? Or were you already thinking about what comes next?
Under real pressure this past month, did joy still show up anywhere — or did it feel like an impossible luxury?
This past month, did the people closest to you experience your joy — or mostly your stress?
In the last week — when someone was talking to you, were you actually there? Or were you half-listening while thinking about something else?
How often in the last 7 days did you catch your mind racing ahead while someone else was still talking?
Think about your most important conversation this week. Were you fully in it — or managing it from a distance?
When the meeting was happening, were you in the meeting? Or were you in your head, planning your response, checking the time?
In the last week, did you give anyone your full, undivided attention — no phone, no half-thoughts, just there?
When something stressful was happening around you, did you stay grounded — or did your nervous system leave the room before your body did?
How often this week did you complete a conversation, a task, or a meal without your mind being somewhere else?
When things got tense this week, did you stay present — or go somewhere safer inside your head?
Think about yesterday. How many moments do you actually remember being fully in — not just going through the motions?
The people closest to you — do they feel like you're actually present with them? Or do they feel you're always somewhere else?
In the last 7 days, how often were you physically in a room but mentally somewhere else?
When you were doing something important this week, did it have your full attention — or were you multitasking?
Under pressure this past month, did you stay present — or did anxiety pull you into future-planning and worst-case scenarios?
In the last month, did you practice any kind of grounding or presence ritual — a breath, a pause, something that brought you back?
When someone needed you to just be there — not fix anything, not advise anything, just be there — were you able to do that?
This past month, did you experience any moments of real stillness — where you weren't rushing toward or away from something?
In the last week, was there something you knew you needed to do — and didn't do it because fear, doubt, or discomfort got in the way?
When you felt uncertain this week, did you move anyway — or wait for the feeling to pass?
Think about a moment in the last 7 days when something felt risky or uncomfortable. Did you step toward it or away from it?
How often this week did you say what you actually thought — even when the room might push back?
When doubt showed up this week, did you recognize it for what it was — a feeling, not a fact — and act anyway?
In the last week, did you advocate for yourself — your time, your ideas, your value — or did you shrink to keep the peace?
Think about a decision you delayed this week. What was the real reason you waited?
When you were asked to do something that didn't align with what you believe is right, what did you do?
In the last 7 days, did you go first in any way — share first, try first, be vulnerable first — or did you wait for someone else to go?
How often this week did you act from your own conviction instead of from what you thought others expected?
The people around you — do they experience you as someone who moves decisively, or someone who needs all the information before moving?
When someone challenged or dismissed your idea this week, did you hold your ground — or did you back down?
In the last month, did you take one risk you were genuinely uncertain about — and do it anyway?
Under pressure this past month, did your courage hold — or did you play it safer than you believe you should have?
In the last month, was there a conversation you knew you needed to have — and kept finding reasons not to?
This past month, did you show up as someone who leads — or someone who waits to be led?
In the last week, when things got hard — did you have a reason that made the hard thing worth it? Or were you just pushing through?
How often in the last 7 days did your daily actions feel connected to something you actually care about?
Think about the work you did this week. Did any of it feel meaningful to you — genuinely, not just productive?
When someone asked why you do what you do this week — did you have a clear answer? An alive one? Not just a rehearsed one?
In the last week, did you make any choices based on what you value — or did urgency and obligation drive most of it?
When you were depleted this week, what kept you going? Was there something that pulled you forward?
How often this week did your work and your sense of purpose feel aligned — like you were doing what you're actually here to do?
Think about the best moment in your work this week. What made it meaningful to you?
When you hit a wall this week, did your sense of purpose give you a way through — or did the wall just win?
The people closest to you — do they know why you do what you do? Or do they mostly see the hustle without the meaning behind it?
In the last 7 days, did you make time for anything that feeds your sense of purpose — or just the things that were urgent?
When an opportunity came up this week, did you filter it through your values — or did you just say yes because it was available?
In the last month, did your life feel pointed somewhere — somewhere you actually want to go?
Under pressure this past month, did you lose the thread of why this matters to you — or were you able to hold onto it?
In the last month, did you have any clear moments of 'this is why I do this' — or has it mostly felt like going through the motions?
This past month, were your biggest investments of time and energy aligned with what you say matters most to you?
In the last week — were there moments where you showed up differently depending on who was in the room? Not adapted, but different — like a different person entirely?
How often in the last 7 days did you say something you didn't actually mean — because it was easier or safer?
Think about who you were at work this week versus at home. Were those the same person, or did you leave part of yourself at the door?
When someone you respect was in the room this week, did you change how you showed up — your voice, your opinions, how much space you took?
In the last week, did you express a real opinion — something you actually believe — in a situation where agreement would have been easier?
How often this week did you feel like you were performing — doing the version of yourself that the situation called for — rather than just being you?
When something bothered you this week, did you say something — or swallow it and move on?
Think about someone who knows you well. Would the way you showed up at work this week feel familiar to them?
In the last 7 days, did you make any decisions based on what you thought others wanted to see — rather than what you actually believe?
When things got emotional or difficult this week, did you let it show — or did you manage it perfectly so nobody would see anything was wrong?
The people around you — do they know what you actually think? Or do they only know the version you decide to let them see?
In the last week, were there moments you felt proud of yourself — not for what you accomplished, but for who you were in a moment?
In the last month, did you have a conversation where you were fully honest — even when honesty was uncomfortable?
Under pressure this past month, did your character hold — or did stress bring out a version of you that you're not proud of?
In the last month, did you let anyone see you struggle — really see it — or did you keep the hard parts to yourself?
This past month, did you feel like yourself more often than you felt like a role you were playing?
In the last week — did any conversation leave you feeling genuinely connected to the other person? Not just caught up, actually connected?
How often in the last 7 days did you listen to someone with your full attention — not planning what you'd say next, just actually listening?
Think about your most important relationship right now. When did you last do something just to invest in it — not fix it, invest in it?
In the last week, did you ask someone how they were doing and actually wait for a real answer?
When someone was struggling around you this week, did you notice? Did you say something?
How often this week did you make someone feel like they mattered to you — not as a task on your list, but as a person?
In the last 7 days, did any relationship get better because of something you did? Or did they just stay where they were?
When someone trusted you with something vulnerable this week — a fear, a struggle, a mistake — what did you do with it?
The people closest to you — do they feel like you're genuinely interested in them? Or do they sometimes feel like they're an item on your agenda?
In the last week, was there a moment where someone needed connection more than advice, and did you give them connection?
How often in the last 7 days did you show up for someone in a way that surprised them — more than they expected?
When a relationship in your life is struggling, do you tend to move toward it — or away from the discomfort?
In the last month, did you invest in any relationship that wasn't convenient or obligatory — just because it matters?
Under pressure this past month, did your relationships get your presence — or just your leftovers?
In the last month, did you have a conversation that changed something — in the relationship, in someone's day, in how they saw themselves?
This past month, were you someone that people felt safe being honest with?
In the last week — when something didn't go as planned, what was your first move? Did you look for what was still possible, or did you start writing the story about why it wouldn't work?
How often in the last 7 days did you catch yourself assuming something couldn't be done — and stop to ask if that was actually true?
Think about a problem you encountered this week. Did you approach it like there was a way through — or did you approach it like a wall?
When you received feedback this week, did you stay open to it — or did your defenses go up first?
In the last week, did you consider a perspective or approach that was genuinely different from your default? Not just hear it — actually consider it?
How often this week did you say 'what if' or 'what else is possible here' — instead of defaulting to the first answer that showed up?
When your plan fell apart this week, did you find another way — or did the disruption take you out of the game?
Think about a belief you've been carrying about your work or your life. Is it still true — or is it just familiar?
In the last 7 days, did you explore any idea or opportunity just because it was interesting — without needing it to fit neatly into something you already know?
The people around you — do they experience you as someone who expands what's possible in conversations, or someone who narrows it?
In the last week, when something felt stuck, did you get creative — try something different, ask a different question — or just push harder?
How often this week did you let someone's different perspective actually land — change your thinking, even a little?
In the last month, did you do anything that surprised even you — that you wouldn't have predicted you'd do or think?
Under pressure this past month, did you stay curious — or did pressure collapse your options down to just survival mode?
In the last month, did you actively look for what you might be missing — or did you mostly see what you already expected to see?
This past month, were you growing — finding new edges, new capacity, new ways of seeing — or were you mostly repeating what already works?
In the last week — when you walked into a room, did the room feel it? Did something shift in the quality of the space when you showed up?
How often in the last 7 days did you consciously decide what kind of energy you were going to bring into a situation — before you arrived?
Think about someone you know who lights up every room they enter. When you're at your best, are you that person?
In the last week, did you go first — offer warmth, encouragement, vulnerability, presence — before it was given to you?
When things were tense or heavy around you this week, did you bring any light to it — or did you absorb the heaviness and add to it?
How often this week did you do something to make someone else feel seen, acknowledged, or valued — not because you had to, but because you chose to?
In the last 7 days, did you inspire anyone — not with a speech, just by how you showed up?
When the people around you were struggling, did they look toward you for something — energy, steadiness, hope? And if they did, did you have it to give?
Think about the people who depend on you. In the last week, did they see the version of you that you want them to model?
How often this week did you lead by example in a way that wasn't asked of you — you just did it because it was who you are?
The people closest to you — do they consistently experience you as a light in their lives? Or is that something that only shows up some of the time?
In the last week, did you show up as the person you want to be — or the person your circumstances made you?
In the last month, can you name a moment where your presence genuinely made a difference for someone else?
Under real pressure this past month, did you radiate — or eclipse? Did you bring light into the hard moment, or did the hard moment cover yours?
In the last month, were you being the change you want to see — in your home, your work, your community?
